76.heading: Seeing Grant Morrison's The Invisibles.
76.title: Our Sentence is Up : Seeing Grant Morrison's The Invisibles
76.author: Patrick Meaney.
notes: (Sequart Journal ; no. 5)
Summary (from SkyRiver): Grant Morrison's graphic novel series, The Invisibles, has been hailed as an ambitious comics masterpiece

but it's also frequently written off as incomprehensible. Meaney provides in-depth analysis that makes sense of the series's complicated ideas, fractured chronology, and delirious blend of fiction and reality. He explores how the series's fictional conspiracy theories fare in the wake of 9/11 and the War on Terror.

(Dragonlance Chronicles ; book 1)
"Welcome to the world of Krynn

formerly a place of beauty and peace, now poisoned by fear and paranoia. Neighbors glare at each other in suspicion. Religious strife tears once tranquil communities apart. Creatures of myth and legend stalk the countryside, sowing terror. As their world descends into darkness, a group of lifelong companions are reunited. Only this ragtag band can save Krynn from the dark forces looming on the horizon
but the bonds of friendship that time could not sever will be sorely tested by overwhelming odds. A long dormant evil has arisen anew
and dispatched an army of reptilian warriors to baptize Krynn in blood. A conflict unlike any other has begun."

228.heading: Seenappa.
228.title: Anathe : based on a popular Kannada novel
228.author: by Prof
228.appears_in: Gopalakrishna Adiga ; script, Kodibettu Rajalaxmi ; English version, Sowmya Devaraj ; art, Gujjarappa.
notes: Bangalore, India : Indya Comics, between 2000 and 2012?
(Illustrated Kannada Classic Novels ; no. 6)

"Anathe is the story built round Padmavati, a woman in distress. After her husband flees the village to escape law as he had failed to repay the loans he had raised, a pregnant Padmavati is forced to quit the house. She walks out and lands at bachelor Seenappa's house in pouring rain. Seenapa considers his duty to help her out but the village community takes offence. It is not proper for a bachelor, living alone, to offer shelter to a woman in his house, even if she is in dire need of help, is the community's argument citing tradition in support of their stand. But Seenappa defies the dicta of the community and stands by her. He tries to locate her husband who, in the meanwhile, gets set to marry another girl thinking that Padmavati might have died. Will they unite? What situation whill she face? Prof. Gopalakrishna Adiga weaves a story which is set in coastal Karnataka in the early '50s."

234.heading: Seers.
234.title: The Foundation
234.author: writer, John Rozum ; art, Chee ; colorist, Pablo Quiligotti ; letterers, Marshall Dillon & Terri Delgado.
notes: "In the 16th century, the fabled French seer Michel de Nostredame ("Nostradamus") authored a series of books that foretold a future filled with cataclysm. His writings made him a famous and wealthy man. Today, most people consider Nostradamus's prophecies a hoax, but that's all part of the plan. The Foundation, a clandestine, centuries-old agency funded by Nostradamus' wealth, operates around the clock and across the globe to decode the seer's mysterious writings, and to continually save the world from his catastrophic predictions."
